title: 108_hr1913
content: The "Rural Housing Tax Credit Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for the purchase of principal residences by first-time rural homebuyers under section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Rural Housing Tax Credit Act of 2003" offers a tax credit to first-time homebuyers in rural areas. The credit is either 10% of the purchase price of the residence or $5,000, whichever is less. There are limitations based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is limited based on adjusted gross income. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is limited based on adjusted gross income. For married individuals filing jointly, the credit is allowable if the residence is qualified for both spouses. For married individuals filing separately, the credit amount is reduced to $2,500. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is allocated among unmarried individuals purchasing a qualified residence, with a maximum credit of $5,000. Definitions for terms like "rural area," "first-time homebuyer," and "principal residence" are provided in the legislation. The terms 'purchase' and 'purchase price' are defined as per section 1400C(e). Any excess credit in a taxable year can be carried forward to the next year. Reporting requirements may be necessary for verification of eligibility for the credit. Recapture of the credit may occur in certain sales situations. If the taxpayer fails to use or disposes of a qualified residence within 5 years of acquiring it after receiving a credit, the tax for that year is increased by the credit recapture amount. The recapture amount is the applicable percentage of the credit allowed to the taxpayer. The taxpayer may be subject to a credit recapture amount if they fail to use or dispose of a qualified residence within 5 years of acquiring it after receiving a credit. The recapture amount is determined by the applicable recapture percentage, which is calculated based on a table provided in the subsection. Interest on the credit amount for prior taxable years is also included in the calculation. No deduction is allowed for this interest under the tax code. The applicable recapture percentage for the sale of a qualified residence is based on a table provided in the subsection. The recapture percentages range from 100% in Year 1 to 0% in Years 6 and thereafter. Year 1 begins on the first day of the taxable year in which the purchase of the qualified residence occurs. The recapture percentage for the sale of a qualified residence is determined by a table in the subsection, ranging from 100% in Year 1 to 0% in Years 6 and beyond. Any tax increase under this subsection does not count towards tax credits or for section 55 purposes. Exceptions to the provisions include disposition due to death, casualty loss, or involuntary conversion. The subsection discusses the recapture percentage for the sale of a qualified residence, with exceptions for disposition due to death, casualty loss, or involuntary conversion. Amendments to the general rule for adjustments to basis are also made. The text chunk discusses amendments to various sections related to tax credits for residences, including changes to sections 24, 25, and 25B as a result of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. The Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 makes amendments to various tax credit sections, including inserting section 25C into existing sections like 26(a)(1) and 1400C(d). Section 25C of the Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 allows first-time rural homebuyers to purchase principal residences. The effective date for these amendments varies depending on the subsection, with some applying to purchases after the enactment date and others to taxable years before or after specific dates.
